creditline:
The William M. Ladd Collection
Gift of Herschel V. Jones, 1916
inscription:
Signature and inscription
inscribed in pencil lower left: [H.13 La Ronde]; inscribed in pencil verso: [63.436]
medium: Drypoint printed in green on Japan paper
signed: signed in pencil on sheet LR: [A. Rodin]
text: Auguste Rodin got the feel of incising tools during a job decorating porcelain at the Sèvres factory. That likely led to experiments with drypoint, a process whereby tiny pools of ink are trapped in the furls of metal that are displaced by the etching needle. When the plate is inked and printed, the trapped ink produces soft, blurry lines, an effect that adds to the sense of movement in La Ronde. One of just twelve drypoints Rodin made, this print was novel in the 1880s for showing dancing nude men. Rodin's sculptural genius is apparent in the strong contours and muscular modeling. Scholars attribute the sober mood to the influence of Dante's Divine Comedy, which Rodin had been reading as background for his sculpture The Gates of Hell.
title: La Ronde
